summary: Internal Bureau of Prisons email chain from July 23, 2019, detailing an incident where Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with marks on his neck, claiming his cellmate attempted to kill him. The document includes a synopsis of the event, medical and psychological assessments, and discussions about his placement.

events.title: Epstein found with neck marks in cell
events.description: At 1:27 a.m., staff responded to Epstein's cell in the Special Housing Unit. He was found lying on the floor in a fetal position with red marks on his neck, unresponsive. He claimed his cellmate attempted to kill him and had been harassing him.

events.title: Epstein placed on suicide watch
events.description: Following the incident, Epstein was placed in hand restraints, escorted to a suicide cell, and placed on suicide watch. A psychological evaluation later that morning determined he should remain on watch.

events.title: Medical assessment of Epstein
events.description: At 6:30 a.m., a Physician Assistant assessed Epstein. Findings included a circular line of erythema on his neck, but Epstein was ambulatory, oriented, smiling, and denied pain or knowledge of how the marks occurred.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center New York, 150 Park Row, New York, New York 10007
keyFacts: On July 23, 2019, Jeffrey Epstein was found in his cell with red marks on his neck and claimed his cellmate had attempted to kill him.
Epstein's cellmate at the time was described as a former police officer pending a death penalty case for murder/triple homicide, arrested in December 2016.
Medical assessment noted Epstein had a circular line of erythema on his neck but was smiling, oriented, and denied pain or knowledge of the event.
Epstein was placed on suicide watch following the incident, and BOP staff were reviewing his case for placement in the general population.
The document reveals internal BOP communications and concerns about Epstein's safety and status while in custody prior to his death.
